Award.AwardTitle: PFI-TT: Initial proof of concept of a novel minimally invasive tool to address urethral narrowing
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this PFI project is to dramatically improve the quality of life for men with urethral stricture disease (USD), by enabling them to undergo a curative minimally invasive treatment. USD is a narrowing of the urinary tract (urethra), similar to a band of scar tissue, causing painful and frequent urination. Nearly 1% of men on Medicare seek treatment for USD, and over $300 million is spent annually on treatment in the United States alone. Current options for these patients are either minimally invasive procedures with high rates of recurrence, or complex open reconstructive surgery of the urethra - only performed by small number of experts. Many patients diagnosed with USD undergo repeat minimally invasive treatments - worsening their condition; their lives revolve around the next painful trip to the restroom. Our innovation will bridge the gap between these approaches, allowing general urologists to provide effective treatment by performing graft reconstruction of the urethra minimally invasively. This will make treatment accessible to patients who don?t have access to an expert surgeon, and to those who are ineligible for a long complex surgery.

The proposed project will develop a prototype for the minimally invasive surgical tool which will be fully integrated. Research objectives include: the development of an anatomically correct urethral model, iterative manufacture and testing of device sub-components, and integration of sub-components into the complete device for functional testing in the urethral model.
Sub-component testing will include measuring the forces exerted upon the graft used for reconstruction during various steps of the procedure, to ensure that the final integrated device design can successfully deliver a graft, and not cause damage to the graft upon device removal. Once sub-components have been tested and modified as needed, they will be integrated into the complete device for testing functionality in the urethral model. The resulting integrated prototype will be fully functional, and be ready for use in a future pilot study in an animal model (beyond PFI-TT).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Urethral stricture disease is distinguished by fibrotic narrowing of the urethra and lower urinary tract symptoms which include restricted, frequent and painful urination. These symptoms dramatically reduce an affected man?s quality of life. Current treatment options include a minimally invasive stricture incision and complex open surgical reconstruction to deliver a tissue graft (urethroplasty). Although simple to perform, minimally invasive management is also minimally effective (<50% success) and when repeated can worsen a patient?s condition. More than $300 million is spent annually treating urethral strictures in the U.S. alone, and since prevalence increases with age and instrumentation, this number is expected to rise in our aging population. The growing number of men affected by urethral stricture disease need a treatment option which is both minimally invasive and clinically effective: endoscopic inlay reconstruction (EIR). Although clinically successful in previous attempts, EIR is not presently feasible due to its complexity relative to open surgery. We have developed a novel solution to bridge this gap, enabling a reliable and repeatable tool to perform endoscopic inlay reconstruction. This device is a temporary graft delivery system that can be deployed endoscopically inside the urethra to the site of the stricture. The technology was developed as part of a collaborative venture between The Johns Hopkins University department of Urology and The Center for Bioengineering Innovation and Design (CBID) in the department of biomedical engineering.

The major objectives of this PFI-TT project are threefold: 1) To develop a modular human-similar bench urethral model which is anatomically accurate for device functional testing. Anatomical 3D models of the human male urinary system were reconstructed from de-identified human prostate MRI scans. These 3D models were subsequently utilized to fabricate a modular bench urethral assembly employing 3D printing and casting techniques with tissue-like materials. A unique characteristic of this modular system is the replaceable urethral tissue component critical for increasing the lifespan of the model. 2) To design, prototype and characterize systems to secure a tissue graft to the novel urethral implant. Reliable graft fixation and separation systems are critical for the success of endoscopic urethroplasty procedures. Over three rounds of iterative design, prototype and testing cycles, multiple graft securement methods ranging from simple passive biodegradable systems to complex active release systems were designed and evaluated. These designs were characterized for joint mechanical forces (Axial tensile, axial shear and 3-point testing) and physician ease of securement/release (time to assemble graft and separate graft). The top 2 designs were later integrated into the full design assembly. 3) To design, prototype and integrate device components and sub-assemblies into a functional system and validate endoscopic urethroplasty under bench settings. Full design prototypes were fabricated and functional testing of the novel endoscopic urethroplasty procedure in the bench urethral model. This involved graft securement, endoscopic device delivery, endoscopic device deployment, delivery system retrieval, retrieval device insertion, graft release, endoscopic implant retraction and retrieval.  Ease of use and time required to perform each procedure was measured. 

 

The milestones accomplished and program learnings have immensely benefited the research team for proof-of-concept validation of the novel technology and propelled us to pursue subsequent funding to further develop the procedure in preclinical models. During the course of the award the research team has formed a university-spinout startup and secured translation funding through NSF and NIH STTR programs. Preclinical studies are currently underway to mitigate biological risks and validate the technology.

Modified by: Edward J Wright
